context: Investitures, which include the conferring of knighthoods by dubbing with <a4_0>a sword<a4_0/>, and other awards take place <a0_0><b7_0>in <b10_0>the palace's <a5_0>Ballroom<b10_0/><b7_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>, built in <a1_0><b8_0>1854<b8_0/><a1_0/>. At 36.6 m (120 ft) long, 18 m (59 ft) wide and 13.5 m (44 ft) high, it is the largest room in the palace. It has replaced <a2_0><a6_0><b9_0>the throne room<b9_0/><a6_0/><a2_0/> in importance and use. During investitures, the Queen stands on <a3_0><b11_0>the throne dais<b11_0/><a3_0/> beneath a giant, domed velvet canopy, known as a shamiana or a baldachin, that was used at the Delhi Durbar in 1911. A military band plays in the musicians' gallery as award recipients approach the Queen and receive their honours, watched by their families and friends.
